label: chapter_2_inheritance_.pdf
title: Classes and Objects: Introduction and Case Study & Access Control and Encapsulation & The 'this' Reference & Constructors and Overloading & 8.6 Default and No-Argument Constructors & 8.7 Notes on Set and Get Methods & 8.11 static Class Members & 8.8 Composition & 8.9 Enumerations & 8.10 Garbage Collection & 8.13 final Variables & 8.14 Time Class Case Study: Creating Packages & 8.15 Package Access and Classpath & 8.16 GUI and Graphics Case Study & 8.17 Wrap-Up and Chapter Summary & Classes and Objects: A Deeper Look & Object-Oriented Programming: Inheritance & Relationship between Superclasses and Subclasses & Inheritance and Method Overriding & Constructors and Class Object & GUI Components and Layout

questions.text: According to Section 8.2, if a class does not declare any constructors, how are `int` instance variables initialized?

choices.label: They are initialized to a random value.
choices.text: They are initialized to a random value.

choices.label: The compiler leaves them uninitialized, causing a compilation error if used.
choices.text: The compiler leaves them uninitialized, causing a compilation error if used.

choices.label: They implicitly receive the default value 0.
choices.text: They implicitly receive the default value 0.

choices.label: They must be initialized manually in the main method.
choices.text: They must be initialized manually in the main method.

questions.explanation: In Java, instance variables that are not explicitly initialized receive a default value. For numeric types like int, this value is 0.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between `String.format` and `System.out.printf` as described in the text?

choices.label: String.format is used for integers only.
choices.text: String.format is used for integers only.

choices.label: String.format returns a formatted String, while printf displays it in the command window.
choices.text: String.format returns a formatted String, while printf displays it in the command window.

choices.label: printf is a static method of class String.
choices.text: printf is a static method of class String.

choices.label: There is no difference; they are aliases for the same method.
choices.text: There is no difference; they are aliases for the same method.

questions.explanation: As noted in the description of method toUniversalString, format returns a formatted String rather than displaying it directly.

questions.text: When is the `toString` method of an object called implicitly?

choices.label: Only when the object is assigned to null.
choices.text: Only when the object is assigned to null.

choices.label: Whenever the object appears where a String is needed, such as in a %s format specifier.
choices.text: Whenever the object appears where a String is needed, such as in a %s format specifier.

choices.label: Every time a private variable is accessed.
choices.text: Every time a private variable is accessed.

choices.label: Only when the developer calls it explicitly using objectName.toString().
choices.text: Only when the developer calls it explicitly using objectName.toString().

questions.explanation: The text states that toString is called implicitly whenever an object appears in code where a String is needed, such as with a %s format specifier.

questions.text: In the `Time1` class example, what happens if an invalid hour (e.g., 99) is passed to `setTime`?

choices.label: The hour is automatically set to 0.
choices.text: The hour is automatically set to 0.

choices.label: The program crashes without any error message.
choices.text: The program crashes without any error message.

choices.label: It throws an IllegalArgumentException.
choices.text: It throws an IllegalArgumentException.

choices.label: The value 99 is stored, but the toString method will fail.
choices.text: The value 99 is stored, but the toString method will fail.

questions.explanation: Lines 23–24 of Fig 8.1 show that the method throws a new IllegalArgumentException if the values are out of range.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the 'public interface' of a class?

choices.label: The private data members and helper methods.
choices.text: The private data members and helper methods.

choices.label: The public methods that a class provides to its clients.
choices.text: The public methods that a class provides to its clients.

choices.label: The source code inside the .java file.
choices.text: The source code inside the .java file.

choices.label: The comments documenting the class implementation.
choices.text: The comments documenting the class implementation.

questions.explanation: The text refers to the public methods (like setTime, toString) as the public services or the public interface provided to clients.

questions.text: What is the result of a method that is NOT a member of a class attempting to access a `private` member of that class?

choices.label: A runtime exception is thrown.
choices.text: A runtime exception is thrown.

choices.label: The program compiles but returns null for that member.
choices.text: The program compiles but returns null for that member.

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: Access is granted if the class is in the same package.
choices.text: Access is granted if the class is in the same package.

questions.explanation: Common Programming Error 8.1 and Fig 8.3 demonstrate that attempting to access private members from outside the class results in a compilation error.

questions.text: Why does Software Engineering Observation 8.2 suggest that implementation details should be hidden?

choices.label: To make the code run faster.
choices.text: To make the code run faster.

choices.label: Because implementations change more frequently than interfaces.
choices.text: Because implementations change more frequently than interfaces.

choices.label: To prevent other developers from stealing the logic.
choices.text: To prevent other developers from stealing the logic.

choices.label: To ensure that all variables are static.
choices.text: To ensure that all variables are static.

questions.explanation: The observation states that interfaces change less frequently than implementations, and hiding details reduces the chance that other program parts become dependent on those details.

questions.text: How many `public` classes can a single source-code (.java) file contain?

choices.label: As many as needed.
choices.text: As many as needed.

choices.label: Exactly two.
choices.text: Exactly two.

choices.label: Only one.
choices.text: Only one.

choices.label: None; public classes must be in .class files.
choices.text: None; public classes must be in .class files.

questions.explanation: Section 8.4 notes that a source-code file can contain only one public class; otherwise, a compilation error occurs.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of `private` variables and methods according to Section 8.3?

choices.label: To allow the compiler to optimize memory usage.
choices.text: To allow the compiler to optimize memory usage.

choices.label: To act as the implementation details not accessible to clients.
choices.text: To act as the implementation details not accessible to clients.

choices.label: To allow subclasses to override them easily.
choices.text: To allow subclasses to override them easily.

choices.label: To define the public interface of the class.
choices.text: To define the public interface of the class.

questions.explanation: The text explains that private members are implementation details and are not accessible to the class's clients.

questions.text: Which access modifier is mentioned as being introduced in Chapter 9?

choices.label: internal
choices.text: internal

choices.label: protected
choices.text: protected

choices.label: friend
choices.text: friend

choices.label: synchronized
choices.text: synchronized

questions.explanation: Section 8.3 states, 'In Chapter 9, we’ll introduce the additional access modifier protected.'

questions.text: What is 'shadowing' in the context of Java classes?

choices.label: When a subclass has the same name as a superclass.
choices.text: When a subclass has the same name as a superclass.

choices.label: When a local variable or parameter has the same name as a class field.
choices.text: When a local variable or parameter has the same name as a class field.

choices.label: When two methods have the same name but different parameters.
choices.text: When two methods have the same name but different parameters.

choices.label: When a private method is called by a public method.
choices.text: When a private method is called by a public method.

questions.explanation: As explained in Section 8.4, shadowing occurs when a method contains a local variable with the same name as a field, hiding the field in the method's scope.

choices.label: To tell the compiler that the variables are static.
choices.text: To tell the compiler that the variables are static.

choices.label: To distinguish between the parameter names and the instance variable names.
choices.text: To distinguish between the parameter names and the instance variable names.

choices.label: Because constructors cannot access instance variables directly.
choices.text: Because constructors cannot access instance variables directly.

choices.label: To ensure the variables are stored in the heap.
choices.text: To ensure the variables are stored in the heap.

questions.explanation: When parameter names are identical to instance variable names, the 'this' reference is required to refer to the instance variables explicitly, as they are shadowed by the parameters.

questions.text: According to Performance Tip 8.1, how does Java conserve storage regarding methods?

choices.label: It maintains only one copy of each method per class, shared by all objects.
choices.text: It maintains only one copy of each method per class, shared by all objects.

choices.label: It deletes methods from memory after they are executed.
choices.text: It deletes methods from memory after they are executed.

choices.label: It converts all methods to static at runtime.
choices.text: It converts all methods to static at runtime.

choices.label: It compresses the method code into a zip format.
choices.text: It compresses the method code into a zip format.

questions.explanation: Performance Tip 8.1 states that Java maintains only one copy of each method per class, while each object has its own copy of instance variables.

questions.text: Can the `this` reference be used inside a `static` method?

choices.label: Yes, but only to access other static members.
choices.text: Yes, but only to access other static members.

choices.label: Yes, but it must be the first statement.
choices.text: Yes, but it must be the first statement.

choices.label: No, it cannot be used in a static method.
choices.text: No, it cannot be used in a static method.

choices.label: Only if the static method is public.
choices.text: Only if the static method is public.

questions.explanation: Section 8.4 mentions that Section 8.11 will explain why keyword 'this' cannot be used in a static method (because static methods are not associated with a specific object).

questions.text: In the `buildString` method of class `SimpleTime`, which of the following is true about calling `toUniversalString()`?

choices.label: It must be called using this.toUniversalString().
choices.text: It must be called using this.toUniversalString().

choices.label: It can be called implicitly or explicitly using the this reference.
choices.text: It can be called implicitly or explicitly using the this reference.

choices.label: It cannot be called from within buildString.
choices.text: It cannot be called from within buildString.

choices.label: It requires a new object of SimpleTime to be called.
choices.text: It requires a new object of SimpleTime to be called.

questions.explanation: Lines 34–35 of Fig 8.4 show that both this.toUniversalString() and toUniversalString() can be used to perform the same task.

questions.text: When using `this()` to call one constructor from another in the same class, where must that call be placed?

choices.label: As the last statement in the constructor.
choices.text: As the last statement in the constructor.

choices.label: Anywhere in the constructor body.
choices.text: Anywhere in the constructor body.

choices.label: As the first statement in the constructor body.
choices.text: As the first statement in the constructor body.

choices.label: In a separate static helper method.
choices.text: In a separate static helper method.

questions.explanation: Common Programming Error 8.3 and the text for Section 8.5 state that calling another constructor via this() must be the first statement in the constructor body.

questions.text: According to Software Engineering Observation 8.3, what is special about the relationship between two objects of the same class?

choices.label: They share the same memory address for instance variables.
choices.text: They share the same memory address for instance variables.

choices.label: One object can access the private members of another object of that same class.
choices.text: One object can access the private members of another object of that same class.

choices.label: They are automatically synchronized by the JVM.
choices.text: They are automatically synchronized by the JVM.

choices.label: They cannot exist in the same package.
choices.text: They cannot exist in the same package.

questions.explanation: Software Engineering Observation 8.3 states that when one object of a class has a reference to another object of the same class, it can access all the second object's data and methods, including private ones.

questions.text: What happens to the default constructor once you declare at least one constructor for a class?

choices.label: The compiler still provides the default constructor.
choices.text: The compiler still provides the default constructor.

choices.label: The compiler will no longer provide a default constructor.
choices.text: The compiler will no longer provide a default constructor.

choices.label: The default constructor becomes private.
choices.text: The default constructor becomes private.

choices.label: You must use the 'default' keyword to keep it.
choices.text: You must use the 'default' keyword to keep it.

questions.explanation: Section 8.5 states, 'Once you declare any constructors in a class, the compiler will not provide a default constructor.'

questions.text: Why does the text recommend calling `set` methods within a constructor instead of direct assignment?

choices.label: It is significantly faster for the JVM.
choices.text: It is significantly faster for the JVM.

choices.label: It simplifies code maintenance and centralizes data validation.
choices.text: It simplifies code maintenance and centralizes data validation.

choices.label: Constructors are not allowed to use the assignment operator (=).
choices.text: Constructors are not allowed to use the assignment operator (=).

choices.label: It prevents the object from being garbage collected.
choices.text: It prevents the object from being garbage collected.

questions.explanation: Software Engineering Observation 8.4 and related text suggest that using set methods simplifies maintenance and reduces errors by ensuring validation logic is not duplicated.

questions.text: What does 'inlining the code' refer to in the context of compiler optimization?

choices.label: Moving all code into a single line to reduce file size.
choices.text: Moving all code into a single line to reduce file size.

choices.label: Replacing a method call with the actual code of the method to improve performance.
choices.text: Replacing a method call with the actual code of the method to improve performance.

choices.label: Converting Java code into C++ code.
choices.text: Converting Java code into C++ code.

choices.label: Automatically adding comments to the code.
choices.text: Automatically adding comments to the code.

questions.explanation: The text defines 'inlining the code' as a technique where the compiler removes calls to simple methods and replaces them with the expanded code of their declarations.

questions.text: What happens if you do not provide any constructors in a Java class's declaration?

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: The class cannot be instantiated.
choices.text: The class cannot be instantiated.

choices.label: The compiler creates a default constructor that takes no arguments.
choices.text: The compiler creates a default constructor that takes no arguments.

choices.label: The compiler creates a default constructor that requires arguments for all instance variables.
choices.text: The compiler creates a default constructor that requires arguments for all instance variables.

questions.explanation: If no constructor is provided, the compiler creates a default constructor that takes no arguments and initializes instance variables to their default values.

questions.text: What is the default value for an instance variable of type `boolean` when initialized by a default constructor?

choices.label: true
choices.text: true

choices.label: false
choices.text: false

choices.label: null
choices.text: null

questions.explanation: In Java, the default value for a primitive boolean instance variable is false.

questions.text: If a class explicitly declares at least one constructor, which of the following is true?

choices.label: The compiler still generates a default constructor.
choices.text: The compiler still generates a default constructor.

choices.label: The compiler will not create a default constructor.
choices.text: The compiler will not create a default constructor.

choices.label: The program will not compile unless the constructor is public.
choices.text: The program will not compile unless the constructor is public.

choices.label: All instance variables must be final.
choices.text: All instance variables must be final.

questions.explanation: As soon as you declare any constructor, the compiler stops providing the automatic default constructor. You must then manually define a no-argument constructor if needed.

choices.label: The compiler-generated default constructor.
choices.text: The compiler-generated default constructor.

choices.label: The no-argument constructor provided by the programmer.
choices.text: The no-argument constructor provided by the programmer.

choices.label: The three-argument constructor directly.
choices.text: The three-argument constructor directly.

choices.label: None; this code results in a syntax error.
choices.text: None; this code results in a syntax error.

questions.explanation: The expression `new Time2()` invokes the user-defined no-argument constructor.

questions.text: What are the default values for primitive numeric types and object references respectively?

choices.label: 1 and null
choices.text: 1 and null

choices.label: 0 and void
choices.text: 0 and void

choices.label: 0 and null
choices.text: 0 and null

choices.label: null and 0
choices.text: null and 0

questions.explanation: Primitive numeric types default to 0, and reference types default to null.

questions.text: What are 'mutator' methods more commonly known as?

choices.label: Accessor methods
choices.text: Accessor methods

choices.label: Query methods
choices.text: Query methods

choices.label: Predicate methods
choices.text: Predicate methods

choices.label: Set methods
choices.text: Set methods

questions.explanation: Set methods are called mutator methods because they typically change (mutate) an object's state.

questions.text: Which type of method is specifically used to test whether a condition is true or false?

choices.label: Accessor method
choices.text: Accessor method

choices.label: Predicate method
choices.text: Predicate method

choices.label: Mutator method
choices.text: Mutator method

choices.label: Static method
choices.text: Static method

questions.explanation: Methods that return boolean values to test conditions, like ArrayList's `isEmpty`, are called predicate methods.

questions.text: Why is it better to use set methods instead of making instance variables public?

choices.label: Set methods execute faster than direct variable access.
choices.text: Set methods execute faster than direct variable access.

choices.label: Set methods can perform validity checking to ensure data integrity.
choices.text: Set methods can perform validity checking to ensure data integrity.

choices.label: Set methods are required by the Java compiler for all private data.
choices.text: Set methods are required by the Java compiler for all private data.

choices.label: Public variables cannot be accessed by other classes.
choices.text: Public variables cannot be accessed by other classes.

questions.explanation: Set methods allow the class to scrutinize attempts to modify data, throwing exceptions or rejecting invalid values (e.g., negative weight).

questions.text: What is the typical return type of a 'set' method that uses exception handling to signal invalid data?

choices.label: int
choices.text: int

choices.label: boolean
choices.text: boolean

choices.label: void
choices.text: void

choices.label: String
choices.text: String

questions.explanation: Typically, set methods have a void return type and use exceptions to handle errors, though they can also return status codes.

questions.text: How do get methods help promote program modifiability?

choices.label: By providing a way to delete instance variables at runtime.
choices.text: By providing a way to delete instance variables at runtime.

choices.label: By allowing clients to directly modify the internal storage format.
choices.text: By allowing clients to directly modify the internal storage format.

choices.label: By shielding client code from the actual data representation.
choices.text: By shielding client code from the actual data representation.

choices.label: By making the class static.
choices.text: By making the class static.

questions.explanation: A get method can control the format of the data it returns, allowing the internal implementation to change without affecting the client.

questions.text: How many copies of a `static` variable are maintained in memory, regardless of how many objects of that class are instantiated?

choices.label: One for every object
choices.text: One for every object

choices.label: Two: one for the class and one for the current object
choices.text: Two: one for the class and one for the current object

choices.label: Zero, until the first object is created
choices.text: Zero, until the first object is created

choices.label: Exactly one
choices.text: Exactly one

questions.explanation: A static variable (class variable) represents classwide information; only one copy of the data is shared by all objects of the class.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT allowed in a `static` method?

choices.label: Accessing public static variables
choices.text: Accessing public static variables

choices.label: Using the `this` reference
choices.text: Using the `this` reference

choices.label: Calling other static methods
choices.text: Calling other static methods

choices.label: Declaring local variables
choices.text: Declaring local variables

questions.explanation: The `this` reference refers to a specific object instance. Since static methods can be called without any instance existing, `this` is unavailable.

questions.text: What is the correct way to call a public static method named `getCount()` in a class named `Employee`?

choices.label: Employee.getCount()
choices.text: Employee.getCount()

choices.label: Employee->getCount()
choices.text: Employee->getCount()

choices.label: new Employee().getCount() only
choices.text: new Employee().getCount() only

choices.label: getCount(Employee)
choices.text: getCount(Employee)

questions.explanation: Public static members should be accessed by qualifying the member name with the class name and a dot.

questions.text: A static method attempts to access a non-static instance variable in the same class. What is the result?

choices.label: A runtime exception is thrown.
choices.text: A runtime exception is thrown.

choices.label: The variable's default value (0 or null) is returned.
choices.text: The variable's default value (0 or null) is returned.

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: The program runs normally if an object exists.
choices.text: The program runs normally if an object exists.

questions.explanation: Static methods cannot access non-static class members (instance variables or instance methods) directly because those require a specific object instance.

questions.text: When do `static` class members become available in memory?

choices.label: Only after the first object is instantiated.
choices.text: Only after the first object is instantiated.

choices.label: As soon as the class is loaded into memory at execution time.
choices.text: As soon as the class is loaded into memory at execution time.

choices.label: When the program's main method terminates.
choices.text: When the program's main method terminates.

choices.label: When the garbage collector runs.
choices.text: When the garbage collector runs.

questions.explanation: Static members exist even when no objects of the class exist; they are initialized as soon as the class is loaded.

questions.text: What is 'composition' in Java?

choices.label: A relationship where a class inherits from another class.
choices.text: A relationship where a class inherits from another class.

choices.label: The process of compiling multiple source files at once.
choices.text: The process of compiling multiple source files at once.

choices.label: A relationship where a class has references to objects of other classes as members.
choices.text: A relationship where a class has references to objects of other classes as members.

choices.label: The ability of a method to return different types.
choices.text: The ability of a method to return different types.

questions.explanation: Composition is a 'has-a' relationship where one class contains references to objects of other classes as fields.

questions.text: Which keyword is used to define a set of constants represented as unique identifiers?

choices.label: constant
choices.text: constant

choices.label: enum
choices.text: enum

choices.label: final
choices.text: final

choices.label: static
choices.text: static

questions.explanation: The `enum` keyword is used to declare an enumeration, which defines a group of named constants.

questions.text: What is the restriction regarding creating objects of an `enum` type?

choices.label: You must use the `new` operator.
choices.text: You must use the `new` operator.

choices.label: Any attempt to use the `new` operator results in a compilation error.
choices.text: Any attempt to use the `new` operator results in a compilation error.

choices.label: Enums can only be instantiated inside static methods.
choices.text: Enums can only be instantiated inside static methods.

choices.label: Enums cannot have constructors.
choices.text: Enums cannot have constructors.

questions.explanation: Enum constants are created by the system; manual instantiation using `new` is strictly forbidden and results in a compilation error.

questions.text: Which static method is automatically generated by the compiler for every `enum` to return an array of its constants?

choices.label: getConstants()
choices.text: getConstants()

choices.label: range()
choices.text: range()

choices.label: values()
choices.text: values()

choices.label: toString()
choices.text: toString()

questions.explanation: The compiler generates the `static values()` method for all enums, returning an array of constants in their declared order.

questions.text: What are the implicit modifiers for enum constants?

choices.label: private and final
choices.text: private and final

choices.label: public and volatile
choices.text: public and volatile

choices.label: static and final
choices.text: static and final

choices.label: abstract and static
choices.text: abstract and static

questions.explanation: Enum constants are implicitly static and final because they represent fixed, shared constants.

questions.text: When is an object considered 'eligible' for garbage collection?

choices.label: When the program finishes execution.
choices.text: When the program finishes execution.

choices.label: When there are no more references to the object.
choices.text: When there are no more references to the object.

choices.label: As soon as the object's `finalize` method is called.
choices.text: As soon as the object's `finalize` method is called.

choices.label: When it contains only null values.
choices.text: When it contains only null values.

questions.explanation: The JVM identifies objects that are no longer referenced as eligible for reclamation by the garbage collector.

questions.text: Why is the `finalize` method generally avoided by Java programmers?

choices.label: It can only be called manually.
choices.text: It can only be called manually.

choices.label: It causes the program to crash immediately.
choices.text: It causes the program to crash immediately.

choices.label: There is no guarantee as to when, or even if, it will be called.
choices.text: There is no guarantee as to when, or even if, it will be called.

choices.label: It requires the class to be static.
choices.text: It requires the class to be static.

questions.explanation: The garbage collector's execution is non-deterministic; it may never run before the program terminates, making `finalize` unreliable for critical resource cleanup.

questions.text: If a `final` instance variable is NOT initialized in its declaration, where MUST it be initialized?

choices.label: In the main method.
choices.text: In the main method.

choices.label: In every constructor of the class.
choices.text: In every constructor of the class.

choices.label: In at least one static method.
choices.text: In at least one static method.

choices.label: It doesn't need to be initialized; it defaults to 0.
choices.text: It doesn't need to be initialized; it defaults to 0.

questions.explanation: Final instance variables that are not initialized at declaration must be initialized in every constructor to ensure they have a value upon object creation.

questions.text: What happens if a program attempts to modify a `final` instance variable after it has been initialized?

choices.label: A runtime exception is thrown.
choices.text: A runtime exception is thrown.

choices.label: The value remains unchanged and the program continues silently.
choices.text: The value remains unchanged and the program continues silently.

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: The variable is deleted from memory.
choices.text: The variable is deleted from memory.

questions.explanation: The keyword `final` makes a variable a constant; the compiler prevents any reassignment.

questions.text: Which principle states that code should be granted only the amount of privilege and access it needs to accomplish its task?

choices.label: The Principle of Least Privilege
choices.text: The Principle of Least Privilege

choices.label: The Principle of Encapsulation
choices.text: The Principle of Encapsulation

choices.label: The Rule of Finality
choices.text: The Rule of Finality

choices.label: The Static Access Principle
choices.text: The Static Access Principle

questions.explanation: The principle of least privilege is a fundamental software engineering concept that advocates for restricted access to improve robustness.

questions.text: What is the correct order of declarations in a Java source-code file?

choices.label: import declarations, package declaration, class declarations
choices.text: import declarations, package declaration, class declarations

choices.label: package declaration, import declarations, class declarations
choices.text: package declaration, import declarations, class declarations

choices.label: class declarations, package declaration, import declarations
choices.text: class declarations, package declaration, import declarations

choices.label: import declarations, class declarations, package declaration
choices.text: import declarations, class declarations, package declaration

questions.explanation: A Java source-code file must follow the order: 1. package declaration (if any), 2. import declarations (if any), then 3. class declarations.

questions.text: Which `javac` command-line option is used to specify where the compiler should create the directories for a package?

choices.label: -p
choices.text: -p

choices.label: -classpath
choices.text: -classpath

choices.label: -d
choices.text: -d

choices.label: -dir
choices.text: -dir

questions.explanation: The -d option causes the javac compiler to create appropriate directories based on the class’s package declaration.

questions.text: According to the text, how should unique package names be formed to avoid naming conflicts?

choices.label: Start with the project name followed by the class name.
choices.text: Start with the project name followed by the class name.

choices.label: Use a random UUID as the package prefix.
choices.text: Use a random UUID as the package prefix.

choices.label: Start with your Internet domain name in reverse order.
choices.text: Start with your Internet domain name in reverse order.

choices.label: Use the keyword 'package' followed by the local directory name.
choices.text: Use the keyword 'package' followed by the local directory name.

questions.explanation: To provide unique package names, it is a convention to start each one with your Internet domain name in reverse order (e.g., com.deitel).

questions.text: If a class `Time1` is in the package `com.deitel.jhtp.ch08`, what is its 'fully qualified class name'?

choices.label: Time1
choices.text: Time1

choices.label: com.deitel.Time1
choices.text: com.deitel.Time1

choices.label: com.deitel.jhtp.ch08.Time1
choices.text: com.deitel.jhtp.ch08.Time1

choices.label: ch08.Time1
choices.text: ch08.Time1

questions.explanation: The package name is part of the fully qualified class name; hence it is the full dot-separated path including the class name.

questions.text: Which statement regarding the import declaration `import java.util.*;` is true?

choices.label: It is a single-type-import declaration.
choices.text: It is a single-type-import declaration.

choices.label: It is a type-import-on-demand declaration.
choices.text: It is a type-import-on-demand declaration.

choices.label: It imports all classes in the Java API.
choices.text: It imports all classes in the Java API.

choices.label: It causes all classes in the util package to be loaded by the JVM immediately.
choices.text: It causes all classes in the util package to be loaded by the JVM immediately.

questions.explanation: An import with an asterisk is a type-import-on-demand declaration. Only the classes actually used in the program are loaded by the JVM.

questions.text: What happens if you do not specify an access modifier (public, private, or protected) for a class member?

choices.label: The member is public by default.
choices.text: The member is public by default.

choices.label: The member is private by default.
choices.text: The member is private by default.

choices.label: The member has package access.
choices.text: The member has package access.

choices.label: The compiler throws an error.
choices.text: The compiler throws an error.

questions.explanation: If no access modifier is specified, the method or variable is considered to have package access, meaning it can be accessed by other classes in the same package.

questions.text: What is a side effect of specifying an explicit classpath using the `-classpath` option?

choices.label: It includes the current directory by default.
choices.text: It includes the current directory by default.

choices.label: It eliminates the current directory from the search path unless it is explicitly included.
choices.text: It eliminates the current directory from the search path unless it is explicitly included.

choices.label: It causes the compiler to ignore standard Java libraries.
choices.text: It causes the compiler to ignore standard Java libraries.

choices.label: It only works for .jar files, not directories.
choices.text: It only works for .jar files, not directories.

questions.explanation: Common Programming Error 8.12 notes that specifying an explicit classpath eliminates the current directory from the search path. To include it, a dot (.) must be added to the classpath.

questions.text: Which object does the compiler use to locate the classes it needs?

choices.label: Class loader
choices.text: Class loader

choices.label: Package manager
choices.text: Package manager

choices.label: Garbage collector
choices.text: Garbage collector

choices.label: Classpath runner
choices.text: Classpath runner

questions.explanation: The compiler uses a special object called a class loader to search standard classes, extension packages, and the classpath.

questions.text: In the context of the classpath, what character is used as a directory separator on Windows systems?

choices.label: Colon (:)
choices.text: Colon (:)

choices.label: Comma (,)
choices.text: Comma (,)

choices.label: Semicolon (;)
choices.text: Semicolon (;)

choices.label: Dot (.)
choices.text: Dot (.)

questions.explanation: On Windows, the semicolon (;) is used as a directory separator, while the colon (:) is used on UNIX/Linux/Mac systems.

questions.text: Why is it generally considered better practice to use the `-classpath` compiler option rather than the `CLASSPATH` environment variable?

choices.label: Environment variables are faster to process.
choices.text: Environment variables are faster to process.

choices.label: The -classpath option allows each application to have its own specific classpath.
choices.text: The -classpath option allows each application to have its own specific classpath.

choices.label: The CLASSPATH variable only supports .zip files.
choices.text: The CLASSPATH variable only supports .zip files.

choices.label: The -classpath option automatically includes the Java standard library.
choices.text: The -classpath option automatically includes the Java standard library.

questions.explanation: Using the command-line option ensures that the classpath is specific to that run, avoiding conflicts between programs that might require different versions of the same package.

questions.text: In the `DrawPanel` example, why are shape coordinates stored in an array rather than just generated randomly during the `paintComponent` call?

choices.label: To improve rendering performance.
choices.text: To improve rendering performance.

choices.label: To ensure the drawing remains consistent every time the system redraws the panel.
choices.text: To ensure the drawing remains consistent every time the system redraws the panel.

choices.label: Because the Graphics object cannot generate random numbers.
choices.text: Because the Graphics object cannot generate random numbers.

choices.label: To comply with JPanel's internal requirements.
choices.text: To comply with JPanel's internal requirements.

questions.explanation: Storing shape data in objects (like MyLine) ensures that the drawing stays the same each time paintComponent is called to refresh the screen.

questions.text: What does the `paintComponent` method of `DrawPanel` use to iterate through and draw the lines?

choices.label: A while loop
choices.text: A while loop

choices.label: An enhanced for statement
choices.text: An enhanced for statement

choices.label: A recursive call
choices.text: A recursive call

choices.label: The System.out.println method
choices.text: The System.out.println method

questions.explanation: The text explains that paintComponent iterates through the MyLine objects in the array using an enhanced for statement (lines 45–46).

questions.text: In the GUI Exercise 8.1, how is the 'width' of a rectangle or oval calculated given two coordinates (x1, y1) and (x2, y2)?

choices.label: x1 + x2
choices.text: x1 + x2

choices.label: The average of x1 and x2
choices.text: The average of x1 and x2

choices.label: The absolute value of the difference between x1 and x2
choices.text: The absolute value of the difference between x1 and x2

choices.label: The larger value between x1 and x2
choices.text: The larger value between x1 and x2

questions.explanation: The instructions specify that the width is the absolute value of the difference between the two x-coordinate values.

questions.text: Which method must be called to actually render a line using a `Graphics` object in Java?

choices.label: `g.renderLine()`
choices.text: `g.renderLine()`

choices.label: `g.drawLine()`
choices.text: `g.drawLine()`

choices.label: `g.paint()`
choices.text: `g.paint()`

choices.label: `g.setCoordinates()`
choices.text: `g.setCoordinates()`

questions.explanation: As seen in the MyLine class (Fig 8.18), `g.drawLine(x1, y1, x2, y2)` is the Graphics method used to draw the line.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `TestDraw` class in Fig. 8.20?

choices.label: To define the shape coordinate logic.
choices.text: To define the shape coordinate logic.

choices.label: To handle the garbage collection of graphics objects.
choices.text: To handle the garbage collection of graphics objects.

choices.label: To create a JFrame window and display the DrawPanel.
choices.text: To create a JFrame window and display the DrawPanel.

choices.label: To serve as the parent class for all shapes.
choices.text: To serve as the parent class for all shapes.

questions.explanation: TestDraw sets up a JFrame, adds the DrawPanel to it, sets its size, and makes it visible.

questions.text: What is the result of using a single `static` import on demand (e.g., `import static myPackage.MyClass.*;`)?

choices.label: It imports all classes within a package.
choices.text: It imports all classes within a package.

choices.label: It imports all static members of a specific class.
choices.text: It imports all static members of a specific class.

choices.label: It allows access to private static members of the class.
choices.text: It allows access to private static members of the class.

choices.label: It prevents the class from being instantiated.
choices.text: It prevents the class from being instantiated.

questions.explanation: A static import on demand imports all static members of a class, allowing you to refer to them without the class name and a dot.

questions.text: Which principle states that code should be granted only the amount of privilege and access that it needs to accomplish its designated task?

choices.label: The Principle of Least Privilege
choices.text: The Principle of Least Privilege

choices.label: The Rule of Private Access
choices.text: The Rule of Private Access

choices.label: The Encapsulation Law
choices.text: The Encapsulation Law

choices.label: The Garbage Collection Principle
choices.text: The Garbage Collection Principle

questions.explanation: As defined in Section 8.13, the principle of least privilege states that code should only have necessary access levels.

questions.text: What is true about `enum` constants?

choices.label: They are mutable at runtime.
choices.text: They are mutable at runtime.

choices.label: They are implicitly static and final.
choices.text: They are implicitly static and final.

choices.label: They can be instantiated using the 'new' keyword.
choices.text: They can be instantiated using the 'new' keyword.

choices.label: They cannot have constructors or methods.
choices.text: They cannot have constructors or methods.

questions.explanation: Enum constants are constants that should not be modified (final) and are class-level members (static).

questions.text: What happens when a local variable in a method has the same name as a field of the class?

choices.label: The compiler throws a name-conflict error.
choices.text: The compiler throws a name-conflict error.

choices.label: The local variable shadows the field.
choices.text: The local variable shadows the field.

choices.label: The field takes precedence over the local variable.
choices.text: The field takes precedence over the local variable.

choices.label: The local variable is automatically renamed.
choices.text: The local variable is automatically renamed.

questions.explanation: If a local variable has the same name as a field, it shadows the field. The 'this' reference must be used to access the shadowed field explicitly.

questions.text: When can a `final` instance variable be initialized?

choices.label: Only at the time of declaration.
choices.text: Only at the time of declaration.

choices.label: Only in the class constructor.
choices.text: Only in the class constructor.

choices.label: At declaration or by each of a class's constructors.
choices.text: At declaration or by each of a class's constructors.

choices.label: Any time before the object is garbage collected.
choices.text: Any time before the object is garbage collected.

questions.explanation: A final variable must be initialized either when it is declared or within the constructors of the class.

questions.text: In the context of class relationships, what does a 'has-a' relationship represent?

choices.label: Inheritance
choices.text: Inheritance

choices.label: Composition
choices.text: Composition

choices.label: Polymorphism
choices.text: Polymorphism

choices.label: Encapsulation
choices.text: Encapsulation

questions.explanation: A 'has-a' relationship represents composition, where an object contains references to other objects as members.

questions.text: What occurs if a programmer specifies a return type (even `void`) for a constructor in Java?

choices.label: It remains a valid constructor.
choices.text: It remains a valid constructor.

choices.label: It results in a compilation error.
choices.text: It results in a compilation error.

choices.label: The compiler treats it as a regular method rather than a constructor.
choices.text: The compiler treats it as a regular method rather than a constructor.

choices.label: The return type is ignored by the JVM.
choices.text: The return type is ignored by the JVM.

questions.explanation: Constructors must not have a return type. If one is specified, Java treats the declaration as a method, which can lead to logic errors when attempting to instantiate the class.

questions.text: In Exercise 8.6, why is the `annualInterestRate` variable declared as `static`?

choices.label: To ensure it cannot be modified after initialization.
choices.text: To ensure it cannot be modified after initialization.

choices.label: To allow each object to have its own unique interest rate.
choices.text: To allow each object to have its own unique interest rate.

choices.label: To store a single value that is shared by all account holders/objects of the class.
choices.text: To store a single value that is shared by all account holders/objects of the class.

choices.label: To make the variable accessible to other packages.
choices.text: To make the variable accessible to other packages.

questions.explanation: Static variables are class-level variables shared by all instances of the class, which is appropriate for a value like a global interest rate.

questions.text: Which type of method is used to return a `boolean` value to test if a specific condition is true or false?

choices.label: Mutator method
choices.text: Mutator method

choices.label: Accessor method
choices.text: Accessor method

choices.label: Predicate method
choices.text: Predicate method

choices.label: Static method
choices.text: Static method

questions.explanation: Predicate methods (like `isEqualTo` or `isZero`) are designed to return a boolean result based on a condition.

questions.text: Which method is called implicitly whenever an object must be converted to a `String` representation, such as in `System.out.printf`?

choices.label: format()
choices.text: format()

choices.label: toString()
choices.text: toString()

choices.label: printString()
choices.text: printString()

choices.label: convertToString()
choices.text: convertToString()

questions.explanation: The `toString` method, inherited from class `Object`, is called implicitly for string conversions.

questions.text: Which keyword is used in Java to create a subclass that inherits from a superclass?

choices.label: inherits
choices.text: inherits

choices.label: implements
choices.text: implements

choices.label: extends
choices.text: extends

choices.label: super
choices.text: super

questions.explanation: The `extends` keyword is used in a class declaration to specify the superclass from which the new class inherits.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about inheritance in Java is true?

choices.label: Java supports multiple inheritance of classes.
choices.text: Java supports multiple inheritance of classes.

choices.label: A subclass can access the private members of its superclass directly.
choices.text: A subclass can access the private members of its superclass directly.

choices.label: Every class in Java directly or indirectly extends class Object.
choices.text: Every class in Java directly or indirectly extends class Object.

choices.label: Constructors are inherited by subclasses.
choices.text: Constructors are inherited by subclasses.

questions.explanation: In Java, all classes inherit from the `java.lang.Object` class. Java only supports single inheritance, and private members remain hidden from subclasses.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the `protected` access modifier?

choices.label: To make members accessible only within the same class.
choices.text: To make members accessible only within the same class.

choices.label: To make members accessible to the class, its subclasses, and other classes in the same package.
choices.text: To make members accessible to the class, its subclasses, and other classes in the same package.

choices.label: To prevent a method from being overridden.
choices.text: To prevent a method from being overridden.

choices.label: To allow access only to classes in different packages.
choices.text: To allow access only to classes in different packages.

questions.explanation: Protected access provides an intermediate level of security, allowing subclasses and package-level classes to access members while hiding them from the general public.

questions.text: When a subclass method has the same signature as a superclass method, it is said to ______ the superclass method.

choices.label: Overload
choices.text: Overload

choices.label: Shadow
choices.text: Shadow

choices.label: Override
choices.text: Override

choices.label: Encapsulate
choices.text: Encapsulate

questions.explanation: Overriding occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass with the same signature.

questions.text: What happens if a subclass constructor does not explicitly call a superclass constructor using `super()`?

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: The compiler implicitly calls the superclass's default or no-argument constructor.
choices.text: The compiler implicitly calls the superclass's default or no-argument constructor.

choices.label: The superclass variables remain uninitialized.
choices.text: The superclass variables remain uninitialized.

choices.label: The program crashes at runtime.
choices.text: The program crashes at runtime.

questions.explanation: The first task of any subclass constructor is to call its superclass constructor. If not done explicitly, Java attempts an implicit call to the superclass's no-argument constructor.

questions.text: What is the benefit of using the `@Override` annotation?

choices.label: It makes the code run faster.
choices.text: It makes the code run faster.

choices.label: It allows the method to access private variables.
choices.text: It allows the method to access private variables.

choices.label: It forces the compiler to check that the method signature matches a method in the superclass.
choices.text: It forces the compiler to check that the method signature matches a method in the superclass.

choices.label: It is required to make a method public.
choices.text: It is required to make a method public.

questions.explanation: The `@Override` annotation prevents accidental overloading by ensuring the compiler verifies that a method with that exact signature exists in the superclass.

questions.text: What keyword is used in Java to indicate that one class inherits from another?

choices.label: inherits
choices.text: inherits

choices.label: implements
choices.text: implements

choices.label: extends
choices.text: extends

choices.label: super
choices.text: super

questions.explanation: Keyword 'extends' indicates inheritance, passing on the capabilities of the superclass to the subclass.

questions.text: In a subclass constructor, what is the requirement for using the `super` keyword to call a superclass constructor?

choices.label: It must be the last statement in the constructor.
choices.text: It must be the last statement in the constructor.

choices.label: It must be the first statement in the constructor.
choices.text: It must be the first statement in the constructor.

choices.label: It can be placed anywhere in the constructor.
choices.text: It can be placed anywhere in the constructor.

choices.label: It is only required if the superclass has no constructors at all.
choices.text: It is only required if the superclass has no constructors at all.

questions.explanation: The explicit superclass constructor call must be the first statement in the subclass constructor's body.

questions.text: Based on the text, what happens if a subclass constructor does not explicitly invoke a superclass constructor and the superclass does not have a no-argument constructor?

choices.label: The program will run but fail at runtime.
choices.text: The program will run but fail at runtime.

choices.label: Java automatically creates a default constructor in the superclass.
choices.text: Java automatically creates a default constructor in the superclass.

choices.label: The compiler issues an error.
choices.text: The compiler issues an error.

choices.label: The subclass members are initialized to null.
choices.text: The subclass members are initialized to null.

questions.explanation: If the superclass lacks a no-argument constructor and the subclass doesn't explicitly call a specific superclass constructor, the compiler issues an error.

questions.text: Why is declaring superclass instance variables as `protected` considered a potential problem for 'fragile' or 'brittle' software?

choices.label: Because subclasses cannot access protected variables.
choices.text: Because subclasses cannot access protected variables.

choices.label: Because changes to the superclass data implementation may require modifying all subclasses.
choices.text: Because changes to the superclass data implementation may require modifying all subclasses.

choices.label: Because protected variables are slower than private variables.
choices.text: Because protected variables are slower than private variables.

choices.label: Because protected variables cannot be used in methods that override superclass methods.
choices.text: Because protected variables cannot be used in methods that override superclass methods.

questions.explanation: Software is 'fragile' when a small change in the superclass (like renaming a variable) can 'break' the implementation of all subclasses that reference that variable directly.

questions.text: Which access modifier allows a subclass to directly access superclass members but keeps them hidden from classes outside the package that are not subclasses?

choices.label: public
choices.text: public

choices.label: private
choices.text: private

choices.label: protected
choices.text: protected

choices.label: static
choices.text: static

questions.explanation: Protected members are accessible by all subclasses and other classes in the same package, but not by unrelated classes in other packages.

questions.text: What is the primary software engineering benefit of using `private` instance variables in a superclass and accessing them via `public` methods in the subclass?

choices.label: It makes the code execute faster.
choices.text: It makes the code execute faster.

choices.label: It allows the superclass implementation to change without affecting subclass implementations.
choices.text: It allows the superclass implementation to change without affecting subclass implementations.

choices.label: It prevents the subclass from inheriting any methods.
choices.text: It prevents the subclass from inheriting any methods.

choices.label: It eliminates the need for constructors in the subclass.
choices.text: It eliminates the need for constructors in the subclass.

questions.explanation: Localizing the effects of changes to the superclass (by using private variables and public getters/setters) prevents the 'brittle' code problem where changes break subclasses.

questions.text: If a class header is declared as `public class CommissionEmployee`, which class does it implicitly extend?

choices.label: The class does not extend anything.
choices.text: The class does not extend anything.

choices.label: Object
choices.text: Object

choices.label: Employee
choices.text: Employee

choices.label: System
choices.text: System

questions.explanation: If a class does not explicitly specify 'extends', it implicitly extends the class 'Object'.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `@Override` annotation in the code examples provided?

choices.label: To indicate a new method that is unique to the subclass.
choices.text: To indicate a new method that is unique to the subclass.

choices.label: To signal the compiler that the method is intended to replace a method from the superclass.
choices.text: To signal the compiler that the method is intended to replace a method from the superclass.

choices.label: To prevent a subclass from changing a method's logic.
choices.text: To prevent a subclass from changing a method's logic.

choices.label: To allow private variables to be accessed from other packages.
choices.text: To allow private variables to be accessed from other packages.

questions.explanation: The `@Override` annotation indicates that a method overrides a superclass method, such as overriding the `toString` or `earnings` methods.

questions.text:
In the code snippet below, what happens when `employee` is printed?

```java
System.out.printf("\n%s:\n\n%s\n", "Updated employee information", employee);
```

choices.label: The memory address of the object is printed.
choices.text: The memory address of the object is printed.

choices.label: A compilation error occurs because a string is expected.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs because a string is expected.

choices.label: The object's `toString` method is invoked implicitly.
choices.text: The object's `toString` method is invoked implicitly.

choices.label: Only the class name is printed.
choices.text: Only the class name is printed.

questions.explanation: When an object is output using the %s format specifier, the object's `toString` method is invoked implicitly to obtain its String representation.

questions.text: What logic error is common when a programmer decides not to use inheritance and instead 'copies and pastes' code from one class to another?

choices.label: It makes the code run too quickly for the processor to handle.
choices.text: It makes the code run too quickly for the processor to handle.

choices.label: It spreads copies of the same code throughout a system, creating a code-maintenance nightmare.
choices.text: It spreads copies of the same code throughout a system, creating a code-maintenance nightmare.

choices.label: It prevents the use of the `public` access modifier.
choices.text: It prevents the use of the `public` access modifier.

choices.label: It forces all instance variables to be `static`.
choices.text: It forces all instance variables to be `static`.

questions.explanation: Copy-pasting code is error-prone, time-consuming, and makes maintenance difficult because changes must be applied to every copy of the code.

questions.text: When overriding a method in a subclass, what keyword is used to invoke the superclass version of that same method?

choices.label: this
choices.text: this

choices.label: base
choices.text: base

choices.label: super
choices.text: super

choices.label: parent
choices.text: parent

questions.explanation: To invoke an overridden superclass method from a subclass, you use the keyword 'super' followed by a dot (.) and the method name (e.g., super.earnings()).

questions.text: What is the likely result if an overridden method in a subclass calls itself without using the `super` keyword?

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: Infinite recursion leading to a StackOverflowError.
choices.text: Infinite recursion leading to a StackOverflowError.

choices.label: The superclass method is called by default.
choices.text: The superclass method is called by default.

choices.label: The program executes successfully but ignores the call.
choices.text: The program executes successfully but ignores the call.

questions.explanation: If the subclass method calls the method name without 'super.', it calls itself, creating infinite recursion which eventually causes the method-call stack to overflow.

questions.text: Which annotation is used to indicate that a method is intended to override a method in a superclass?

choices.label: @Overload
choices.text: @Overload

choices.label: @Inherit
choices.text: @Inherit

choices.label: @Override
choices.text: @Override

choices.label: @Replace
choices.text: @Replace

questions.explanation: The @Override annotation tells the compiler that the method is meant to override a superclass method, helping to prevent errors like accidental overloading.

questions.text: In the provided text, why does `BasePlusCommissionEmployee` call `super.earnings()` inside its own `earnings` method?

choices.label: Because it is required by the Java compiler.
choices.text: Because it is required by the Java compiler.

choices.label: To avoid duplicating the code that calculates commission-based earnings.
choices.text: To avoid duplicating the code that calculates commission-based earnings.

choices.label: To reset the base salary to zero.
choices.text: To reset the base salary to zero.

choices.label: To access private instance variables directly.
choices.text: To access private instance variables directly.

questions.explanation: Calling the superclass method is good software engineering because it allows the subclass to reuse the existing logic for calculating commission without duplicating code.

questions.text: Which statement regarding `protected` members is true based on the text?

choices.label: They are only accessible within the class they are declared.
choices.text: They are only accessible within the class they are declared.

choices.label: They cannot be accessed by subclasses.
choices.text: They cannot be accessed by subclasses.

choices.label: They provide a level of protection between public and private.
choices.text: They provide a level of protection between public and private.

choices.label: They are accessible to every class in any package.
choices.text: They are accessible to every class in any package.

questions.explanation: Protected members can be accessed by members of the superclass, its subclasses, and other classes in the same package, offering intermediate protection.

questions.text: When a subclass object is instantiated, which constructor in the inheritance chain finishes executing last?

choices.label: The Object class constructor.
choices.text: The Object class constructor.

choices.label: The direct superclass constructor.
choices.text: The direct superclass constructor.

choices.label: The original subclass constructor.
choices.text: The original subclass constructor.

choices.label: The first indirect superclass constructor.
choices.text: The first indirect superclass constructor.

questions.explanation: The chain of constructor calls goes up to the Object class first. The Object constructor completes first, and the original subclass constructor's body finishes last.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT a method of the Java `Object` class as described in the text?

choices.label: getClass
choices.text: getClass

choices.label: toString
choices.text: toString

choices.label: hashCode
choices.text: hashCode

choices.label: setText
choices.text: setText

questions.explanation: setText is a method associated with GUI components like JLabel, whereas getClass, toString, and hashCode are part of the Object class inherited by all objects.

questions.text: What is the default implementation of the `equals` method in class `Object`?

choices.label: It compares the contents of two objects.
choices.text: It compares the contents of two objects.

choices.label: It uses the == operator to see if two references refer to the same object.
choices.text: It uses the == operator to see if two references refer to the same object.

choices.label: It always returns true if the objects are of the same type.
choices.text: It always returns true if the objects are of the same type.

choices.label: It compares the hash codes of the two objects.
choices.text: It compares the hash codes of the two objects.

questions.explanation: The default 'equals' implementation in class Object uses the == operator to determine if two references refer to the exact same object in memory.

questions.text: Why is the use of the `clone` method often discouraged by industry experts?

choices.label: It is too slow for modern applications.
choices.text: It is too slow for modern applications.

choices.label: It can only copy primitive types.
choices.text: It can only copy primitive types.

choices.label: Implementing it correctly is difficult; object serialization is often preferred.
choices.text: Implementing it correctly is difficult; object serialization is often preferred.

choices.label: It automatically performs a deep copy which is memory intensive.
choices.text: It automatically performs a deep copy which is memory intensive.

questions.explanation: The text notes that implementing 'clone' correctly is difficult and its use is discouraged in favor of object serialization.

questions.text: What happens if a subclass constructor does not explicitly call a superclass constructor?

choices.label: The program will not compile.
choices.text: The program will not compile.

choices.label: Java implicitly calls the superclass's default or no-argument constructor.
choices.text: Java implicitly calls the superclass's default or no-argument constructor.

choices.label: No superclass constructor is ever called.
choices.text: No superclass constructor is ever called.

choices.label: The object is created without superclass instance variables.
choices.text: The object is created without superclass instance variables.

questions.explanation: If not called explicitly via 'super', Java implicitly calls the superclass's default or no-argument constructor.

questions.text: Which class is used in Java Swing to display text, an image, or both?

choices.label: JFrame
choices.text: JFrame

choices.label: JLabel
choices.text: JLabel

choices.label: ImageIcon
choices.text: ImageIcon

choices.label: BorderLayout
choices.text: BorderLayout

questions.explanation: In package javax.swing, an object of class JLabel can display text, an image, or both.

questions.text: What is the default layout manager for a `JFrame`?

choices.label: FlowLayout
choices.text: FlowLayout

choices.label: GridLayout
choices.text: GridLayout

choices.label: BorderLayout
choices.text: BorderLayout

choices.label: BoxLayaout
choices.text: BoxLayaout

questions.explanation: The text states that the default layout for a JFrame is known as a BorderLayout.

questions.text: If you call `application.add(component)` on a JFrame without a second argument, where is the component placed?

choices.label: NORTH
choices.text: NORTH

choices.label: SOUTH
choices.text: SOUTH

choices.label: CENTER
choices.text: CENTER

choices.label: WEST
choices.text: WEST

questions.explanation: When calling method add with one argument, the JFrame places the component in the CENTER automatically.

questions.text: Which method is used to update the text displayed by a `JLabel` after it has been created?

choices.label: updateText
choices.text: updateText

choices.label: setText
choices.text: setText

choices.label: drawString
choices.text: drawString

choices.label: setLabel
choices.text: setLabel

questions.explanation: Method setText can be called on any JLabel to change its text.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the five regions of a `BorderLayout`?

choices.label: NORTH
choices.text: NORTH

choices.label: MIDDLE
choices.text: MIDDLE

choices.label: EAST
choices.text: EAST

choices.label: CENTER
choices.text: CENTER

questions.explanation: BorderLayout has five regions: NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, WEST, and CENTER. 'MIDDLE' is not a region.
